title: Tu cápsula nespresso donde tu quieras.
body:
Me informe bien antes de la compra, mire los otros modelos de wacaco pero al final que si el adaptador para capsulas, que si el accesorio barista para mas agua, los "que si" se acumulaban y al final mucho dinero. Al final encontré que Wacaco tenía este modelo e indagé sobre el. Precisamente corregía, al menos bajo mi punto de vista, todo aquellos "defectos" de los otros modelos el poder poner la cápsula sin tener que comprar el adaptador, es más pequeña por lo tanto más cómoda de llevar y al menos a mí me parecía más facil de rellenar.

Me llegó y ¿Qué vas ha hacer? Pues un café. Compre unas capsulas originales y otras compatibles, si se prueban las cosas se pruebas bien.

Cosas buenas:
-La máquina es muy sencilla, se prepara en un momento.
-El café esta bueno.
-Muy fácil de limpiar.
-Las cuchillas para perforar las capsulas, tu capsula se va a abrir si o si.
-Da igual capsulas originales o compatibles, funcionan igual de bien.

Cosas malas:

-El agua debe estar hirviendo o lo más caliente posible. Eso es debido a que cuando pasa por la máquina pierde temperatura y la perdida se nota, ya depende del gusto de cada cual con respecto a querer café mas caliente o frio.. Esto se puede solucionar facilmente precalentando, le echas agua caliente la dejas hay un poco, un minuto por ejemplo y bombeas ese agua para que se caliente todo el mecanismo. Luego te haces tu café tan normal y listo, sin problema.

Recomendaciones:
-Si se puede precalentar mejor.
-Al bombeo hay que cogerle el truco, es mejor un bombeo con presion uniforme y constante, así se consiguen los mejores resultados.
-Para bombear, si lo haces con los dedos se puede sin problema pero es más comodo entrelazar las manos apoyando la palanca de bombeo en una de las manos y dejar que los brazos hagan el trabajo(como si quisieras aplastarlo).

Conclusión:

Funciona muy bien, cumple con lo que dice y buen producto. Eso si, recuerda, cuanto más caliente el agua mejor. :)

title: Incredibile
body:
YouTube è piena di video del prodotto in questione, quindi inutile dilungarsi troppo, basta andare a vederne qualcuno. Quello che mi preme mettere in evidenza è quanto sia incredibile avere la possibilità di prepararsi un espresso al volo, con un oggetto così piccolo e leggero, privo di alimentazione elettrica.

Confrontata con la Outin Nano (funzionamento a batteria con possibilità di scaldare automaticamente l’acqua) e utilizzando le stesse capsule compatibili Nespresso il risultato è pressoché identico.

Per chi se lo stesse chiedendo, non c’è una vincitrice tra le due, in quanto si tratta di due prodotti indirizzati ad esigenze differenti, con pesi e ingombri diversi ed i loro pro e contro.

Parlando del funzionamento è tutto molto semplice, basta inserire la capsula nell’apposito alloggiamento, avvitare per bene, aggiungere acqua bollente, chiudere il coperchio, estrarre la pompetta ed azionarla con movimenti fluidi fino alla completa erogazione del caffè.

Il serbatoio ha una capienza di circa 80 ml d’acqua, al contrario della Outin Nano sono assenti tacche per regolarsi con il riempimento, consiglio all’inizio di eseguire alcune prove e comunque attenersi a circa 50 ml d’acqua per evitare caffè troppo lunghi (poi è una questione di gusti).

Ho letto diverse lamentele di persone che non riescono a rimuovere l’estremità di uscita al termine dell’erogazione, questo per via della pressione generata dall’operazione: è sufficiente attendere qualche istante per lasciare raffreddare la macchinetta, togliere il coperchio e premere alcune volte la pompetta, vedrete che sarà possibile rimuovere l’estremità senza alcuna difficoltà.

L’azionamento della pompetta richiede una certa dose di forza, per cui il prodotto è sconsigliato a chi soffre di patologie alle mani, tendiniti ecc. Consiglio di tenere la macchinetta con una mano ed esercitare pressione con il palmo dell’altra mano come raffigurato sul manuale di istruzioni, farete meno fatica.

I materiali sono di qualità ed il prodotto restituisce una buona sensazione di solidità.

Secondo me è un prodotto che merita 5 stelle, a patto di comprenderne la destinazione d’uso e di non pretendere più di quello per cui è stato progettato.

title: Travel light and still get your fix
body: I admit to loving coffee gadgets. I drink one double Nepresso latte in the morning--and I like my coffee the way I like my coffee. I'm not a snob just a creature of habit. So, when I went to visit my mom for a few weeks, I needed a way to keep the coffee flowing. Enter this little bundle of joy. Small enough to take on the plane with me, it worked better than I expected. Are there issues with the pod getting stuck, yup, but you'll figure it out (it isn't that hard). Did I burn my hands pouring the hot water into the container--sure--but that was me not paying attention. Did my hand cramp into a permanent claw trying to pump the machine--absolutely. But ultimately, I got to have my coffee almost my way. I figure I can throw this thing, a small milk frother, and a box of Peets pods into my bag any time I have to travel and I'm set to go. All you need is some boiling water (and hot milk if that is your thing) and you're good. They include a little cup for the hikers and campers, but I skipped that in favor of a regular mug. You'll get some sputtering and, no, the coffee won't be as good as out of the machine, but it will certainly get you through a few days or more. I was quite pleased with the quality of the shots. Make sure to try it out before you go--there is a learning curve but not a steep one. It is easy to carry, easy to clean, and easy enough to use. This is a useful addition to the gadget collection.

title: A Remarkable Upgrade for Espresso Enthusiasts
body:
This review is a testament to the exceptional qualities of the Minipresso NS2, a significant improvement over its predecessor, the Nanopresso. For those unfamiliar with the Nanopresso, it was Wacaco's initial offering designed to support Nespresso capsules.

Although the Nanopresso was a delightful machine, it occasionally suffered from blow-by issues and lacked compatibility with non-Nespresso brand capsules. Blow-by occurs when water bypasses the coffee grounds inside the capsule, affecting the quality of the brew. The Minipresso NS2 rectifies these issues with finesse while boasting a sleek and compact design.

Having been a dedicated consumer of Wacaco products for over five years, I can confidently vouch for their functionality and quality. The Minipresso NS2 surpasses its predecessors in several key aspects:

1. Efficient Heating: The Minipresso NS2 features an innovative design that introduces hot water directly into the machine, eliminating the need for pre-heating. This enhances convenience and saves time.
2. Streamlined Espresso Cup: The Minipresso NS2 incorporates a thinner espresso cup, removing the necessity to preheat it separately. This not only simplifies the process but also enhances the overall experience.
3. Simplified Design: With a smaller footprint and fewer parts, the Minipresso NS2 exudes durability and robustness. It's a testament to thoughtful engineering, making it more user-friendly and long-lasting.
4. Included Drip Cup: Surprisingly, the Minipresso NS2 comes equipped with a small drip cup, which proves to be a valuable addition. It efficiently manages any spills or drips and doubles as a stand, further enhancing the cleanliness and ease of your brewing experience.

Whether you're new to the world of portable espresso machines or a loyal Nanopresso user, the Minipresso NS2 is an upgrade that's well worth considering. Its performance improvements, compact design, and convenient features make it a standout choice for coffee lovers on the go. Say goodbye to blow-by issues and explore the delightful world of espresso with the Minipresso NS2.

title: Oggetto fantastico...ma anche pratico?
body:
Solitamente le vacanze che trascorro all'estero sono l'occasione per fare un periodo "depurativo" dalla caffeina, vista la non sempre semplice reperibilità di un bar con un espresso accettabile, ma dopo aver notato come in ogni casa affittata o camera di hotel prenotata fosse disponibile un bollitore ho deciso di acquistare questa macchina per il caffè manuale approfittando degli sconti per il Black Friday per non privarmi del piacere di un caffè ogni tanto anche senza bar a disposizione.
Nota importante a margine: già a casa utilizzo le capsule compatibili con questo oggetto, quindi non ne devo acquistare apposta.
Innanzitutto, bisogna dire che la macchina manuale è un capolavoro di tecnologia: non utilizza elettricità, l'acqua già calda deve essere pompata tramite un pistone attraverso la parte che contiene la capsula per ottenere poi un bel caffè che non ha niente da invidiare a quello prodotto dalla controparte elettrica.
Finito l'effetto "wow", ci si rende però conto della poca praticità: come detto, l'acqua deve essere messa nella macchina già calda (non è il modello che la scalda da sola, è totalmente manuale), quindi avete necessariamente bisogno di avere sottomano un bollitore o un fornello (o acqua del rubinetto mooooolto calda), e possibilmente dell'acqua per la successiva pulizia delle parti entrate a contatto con il caffè. Inoltre l'utilizzo non è così rapido: le istruzioni sono chiare e la macchina è intuitiva, ma comunque 5 minuti per preparare un caffè ci vogliono tutti.
Se pensate di acquistarla per i vostri viaggi in tenda di più giorni, vi consiglio di proseguire con le bustine di caffè solubile (o con moka e fornelletto, se siete più raffinati), mentre può avere già più senso se siete in camper o comunque in un campeggio. Soluzione interessante se visitate paesi senza la cultura del caffè: le dimensioni sono all'incirca quelle di una bottiglietta da mezzo litro, quindi sta comodamente in un bagaglio a mano senza rubare troppo spazio (c'è anche una sacca per il trasporto e un piccolo pennello per la manutenzione).
Di per sé l'oggetto merita 5 stelle, al momento funziona benissimo (fatto testo con capsule originali in allumino e acqua da bollitore) e il caffè è davvero ottimo, ma la poca praticità e la difficile manutenzione non lo rendono poi così pratico in quelle situazioni senza la disponibilità di acqua calda o corrente per le quali in realtà sarebbe stato concepito e dove, al netto di queste problematiche, funziona alla grande.
Più che altro vale la pena ragionare se si possa fare a meno del caffè in mezzo alla natura selvaggia, e nel caso effettuare l'acquisto a prezzo scontato.

title: This is genius! Get it!
body:
As an espresso lover, I used to struggle on work trips to Eastern Europe and Africa because I couldn't find a decent shot to save my life (they drink real coffee there.) So, I went on a quest for the perfect portable espresso machine, small, practical, without lots of parts, and one that takes espresso pods.... and luckily I stumbled upon this one!

At first, I was on the hunt for an electric espresso maker, but the price tag was unjustifiable. Plus, the size of some of those contraptions was going to take some real estate in my luggage. So, I settled for this cute little manual machine, even though the thought of pumping it 20 times for one tiny shot didn't exactly make me want to do a happy dance.

But, let me tell you, this little one packs a punch! The entire process from boiling the water to pumping out a perfectly extracted shot takes less than 3 minutes. Sure, I have to do a bit of arm work to get my caffeine fix, but its not as horrid as I imagined (memories of manual orange juicers when I had to squeeze 3 oranges to get half a cup). And, there's something oddly satisfying about making my own espresso without having to rely on electric machines.

I also own a Nespresso Creatista machine, which has more features than I know what to do with. So, it's refreshing to use a simpler device that performs just as well. Plus, I can use my espresso pods with this portable device. Most other portable machines, including the original of this one, do not have espresso pods feature or would require you to buy an attachment. I really dont use coffee grounds and dont want to make a mess of this when I am traveling or worry too much about cleaning, so the espresso pod was perfect for me!

I also ordered an electric kettle that works worldwide for tea but it will also pair greatly with this Minipresso on the go without worrying about finding hot water.

Finally, this was easy to figure out without reading the manual. That was great. And, major props to the creators for providing a manual in multiple languages. Even though I didn't need it, it's always nice to have the option.

I am sure I am going to be using this now everywhere I go as it fits nicely in my purse. The only negative issue I found is the cup attached to it. I dont know if it's BPA free, but even if it is, BPA free cups become affected when they are heated. I wish it was a stainless steel cover instead.

Overall, I highly recommend this Minpresso. It does not compromise on taste or quality. Easy to use and really practical. I am a happy customer.

I must say - it's genuinely life changing! Much as I'll still hunt out a good coffee shop - when my options are limited (I'm in rural Japan right now) - this is an absolute life saver. In fact I carry a tin of that around with me as well where ever I go. ) As for the device itself - it's a lovely item. It's built very well and clearly high quality. It makes an excellent single shot expresso - the tank holds enough to make a double in my opinion - though I've always leaned toward the ristretto so maybe I'm not the person to ask. As per my friends advice - I warm the tank up first with boiling water before refreshing with new hot water and operating the device. The coffee comes out at the perfect temperature with an excellent cremma. I've used Starbucks capsules so far and they fit well with no leakage or issues. (Note - do not judge this device if you use it with poor quality capsules I would say - they often fail and leak in counter top machines so I would assume they would in this. Stick to the better brands!) To improve the experience - next time I travel I will bring a small expresso cup with me as well - though the plastic one supplied is adequate for it's purpose. Anyway - signing off - I'm in need of another expresso fix. Enjoy!

title: Won’t pierce Lavazza and L’Or Capsules.
body:
I had the previous version of the Minipresso and it worked just fine. I was looking forward to this so-called improved version since it was smaller and had fewer parts to fuss with. I am now on a two-month trip overseas and find that the NS2 (at least mine) has a defective design or manufacture.

I tried it at home with just water and all seemed well. But now I find that the capsule chamber is too deep to pierce L’Or and Lavazza brand capsules. I haven’t tried the Nespresso capsules yet because their stores are few and far between. But all brands worked on my previous model. The only way I can make espresso with the NS2 is to pre-pierce the capsules a few times with a fork tong, but that allows more grounds to pass through because the tong holes are a little too large. I also tried removing the orange ring gasket that tops the capsule chamber in order to make it more shallow. Then the capsules would properly pierce, but the unit leaks because it needs the orange gasket in place.

A severe disappointment. This is either a design defect or failure in quality control on the part of Wacaco. And there’s nothing I can do about it for the next two months.

title: Easy, beautiful crema every time until it broke.
body:
I am updating from my original glowing 5-star review.
After a little over a week of use without any issue, the bottom portion with the espresso capsule is completely stuck and it will not unscrew. The pressure inside somehow fused the seams. The espresso will not extract from pressing in the pump knob which is impossible to push in.
I am so bummed because I thought that I found the holy grail of travel espresso makers, but unfortunately it is a dud and I will be returning.
****************************************************

I didn't have high expectations, but this little espresso machine is truly impressive!
I travel often for work and getting a good cup of coffee while staying in some hotels is nearly impossible. I used to travel with a small French press, collapsible kettle and my own pre-ground coffee, but the set up was not only cumbersome, but cleanup was tedious and hard without a home set up and supplies. This manual espresso maker has changed the game.
It is compact, easy to use, makes beautiful crema every time, and clean up takes seconds. I am blown away with how well it works.
The make is sturdy and all the pieces fit together easily. I have found that the first 8 pumps fill the nespresso pod, then the next 40 extract the espresso. There is resistance when pushing the pump knob to create pressure, but I didn't find it too hard when using both hands and my palm for added pressure.
I think that it pulls a shot as well as any model of nespresso machine, you just have to do the work, but again, it takes less than a minute from adding the pod, water and then extracting the shot.
I am so pleased with this machine, it has small enough to fit in a carry-on or large purse, so can literally be taken everywhere and if you have access to hot water, you can have espresso anywhere.

title: Portable and Manual Coffee Machine for True Connoisseurs
body:
If you are a coffee lover who enjoys making your own espresso shots, you might be interested in the Flair Espresso Maker. This is a portable and manual coffee machine that claims to produce café-quality espresso without electricity, pods or filters. It consists of a detachable brewing head, a lever press, a preheat cylinder, a stainless steel tamper and a custom pressure gauge. It also comes with a carrying case for easy storage and travel.

I bought this product from Amazon a few weeks ago and I have been using it almost every day since then. I have to say that I am impressed by the quality and taste of the espresso it produces. It is very handy for travel and easy to store. It saves me some time without grinding coffee beans. The coffee taste is very nice and much better than the Nespresso machine.

However, this product is not perfect and it has some drawbacks that you should be aware of before buying it. First of all, it is very expensive compared to other coffee machines. It costs £59.90 on Amazon, which is quite a lot for a manual device. Second, it is extremely hard to press especially if you want to do more than one cup. You need to have strong muscles to finish the job. Third, you need hot water to carry with you and if you like latte you need a milk frother as well.

So, who should buy this product? I think this product is suitable for people who:

- Appreciate the art and science of making espresso
- Want to have full control over the brewing process and variables
- Prefer a rich and smooth espresso with a thick crema
- Don’t mind spending more money and effort for a better coffee experience
- Travel frequently and want to enjoy espresso anywhere

On the other hand, who should avoid this product? I think this product is not suitable for people who:

- Are looking for a cheap and easy way to make coffee
- Don’t care much about the quality and taste of espresso
- Want to make multiple cups of coffee quickly and effortlessly
- Don’t have access to hot water or a milk frother
- Have limited space or budget for a coffee machine

In conclusion, the Flair Espresso Maker is a unique and innovative product that offers a portable and manual way to make espresso. It delivers excellent results in terms of flavour and crema, but it also requires more time, money and strength than other coffee machines. It is ideal for true connoisseurs who enjoy the craft of making espresso, but not for casual drinkers who just want a quick and easy cup of coffee.

body:

CONTRO 😮: prezzo - richiede acqua bollente - richiede discreta forza.

Essendo camperista e appassionato di caffè espresso mi ritrovo spesso a non poter utilizzare la classica macchina elettrica a capsule quando non ho l'allaccio alla 220v. Per questo ho voluto dare una possibilità a questa mini macchina del caffè manuale.

☕ Parto subito col dire che chi vuole il caffè espresso in capsula di qualità pressoché identica al corrispondente fatto con la macchina elettrica, questa è un'ottima soluzione. Basta inserire una capsula (uso un marchio molto conosciuto compatibile), aggiungere acqua bollente , chiudere bene, e cominciare a premere il tasto laterale. Se usi acqua davvero bollente il caffè viene ottimo e caldo. Ho apprezzato il fatto che nella sua compattezza sono inclusi accessori utili come un pennellino di pulizia, un bicchiere e un raccogli gocce.

☕ Ha alcuni aspetti che vanno valutati attentamente. Primo il prezzo, per carità, il risultato finale nel mio caso è ottimo, ma si paga, costa quanto una macchina elettrica. È
da sottolineare che i materiali sono molto robusti. Inoltre serve acqua bollente. O ne hai a disposizione al momento o devi usare un buon termos, altrimenti il caffè verrà tiepido. Poi, anche se sono un uomo di lavoro, ci vuole discreta forza per erogare un caffè, la pompa è dura, niente di impossibile, ma per alcune persone con mani poco robuste può essere faticoso.

Ma nel complesso, da camperista che non ama la moka, è una buona soluzione per avere un buon caffè ovunque, anche senza corrente elettrica. Ne sono soddisfatto, mi sta dando molte soddisfazioni. Spero che duri, in caso di novità aggiornerò la recensione.👍

title: NS2 Review with Update
body:
UPDATE 1.3.2024: I bought the NS2 May 2023. After using it multiple times throughout the year, it simply stopped pumping water through the device as of December 2023. I emailed customer support, who, responded within 24 hours. After providing video proof that device was no longer operative, they agreed to send me a replacement free of charge. I just received the replacement and so far so good. I’m sorry other reviewers seemed to have issues with customer support. I think the support I received was helpful and responsive. Keep in mind that support may be located overseas, so, there might be a business day delay before you get a reply.

Original review from 5.8.2023: I have the original NS model of this device, which, I love. I've been using that one for over a year. However, I took a chance and purchased this upgraded version, the NS2, and so far I'm pleased with it. The NS2 is smaller, lighter, and the piston action is much quieter than on the original model. Also, there is a separate carrying case for purchase that includes a compartment for coffee pods, a small tray, and a mini towel to keep things neat. The crema is just as good as a regular electric espresso machine. Some other users have complained about the stiffness of the cap on the water tank when you screw it back on. I do agree it is a little tricky, but with continued use it seems to get easier. Not sure if that's helpful to know.

title: Simple, easy, quick cleanup. (Great for backpacking)
body:
Information helpful for camping/backpacking and home use: I tested several similar options. This design is perfect for backpacking with a high caffeine-to-pack weight ratio! Extremely compact/lightweight (my scale showed it to weigh 10.6 grams) and extremely convenient with easy cleanup (literally run a little water over it, and you’re good. NO GROUNDS TO CLEANUP!). The hotter your water (close to 200 degrees F) is, the better the extraction. My tests produced a nice crema with great flavor, followed by a boost in energy!

A couple of pods, and I’m set for my morning caffeine needs. If you want more of a “drink,” boil more water and mix it with the espresso for a backcountry Americano.

If you want a unit that works with the original Nespresso pods and coffee grounds, look at the Nanopresso by Wacaco and get the Nanopresso NS Adapter. It’s only 3-4 ounces more packed weight and a couple of inches larger in your pack.

Something I’d like to see is a unit about this size with metal internals. The food-grade plastic internals tends to shed heat faster, so I recommend getting right to it after pouring your boiling water for a hot extraction for the best result.

Stay caffeinated, friends.
